repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Second, Third, and Fourth
            Structural Adjustment; Public Enterprise Sector
            Rationalization & Privatization Technical Assistance;
            and Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The five projects examined for Guinea,
            the Second, Third, And Fourth Structural Adjustment, Public
            Enterprise Sector Rationalization & Privatization
            Technical Assistance, and Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credits have outcomes ranging from moderately unsatisfactory
            to unsatisfactory.  In all projects the sustainability is
            unlikely and Bank and Borrower's performances are
            considered highly unsatisfactory with modest or negligible
            institutional development. The main lessons derived from
            these operations for the Bank are: adjustment lending
            operations should be underpinned by a high quality and
            adequate economic and sector work program; time-bound,
            monitorable indicators should be used to verify performance;
            both revenue and expenditure issues should be addressed in
            reducing fiscal deficits; single tranche credits should be
            used only when the government has an established track
            record of good policy performance; IDA staff re-assignments
            should not be disruptive to IDA operations and client
            relations; timely warning should be given to management and
            the Board of rising IDA risk exposure from an unsustainable
            debt burden; and donor lending can create incentives to
            mismanage the economy

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Fourth Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's outcome is rated
            satisfactory. The reforms supported by the project are
            likely to be sustainable. Given the rating of lending and
            supervision work, the Bank's overall performance is
            rated satisfactory. The Borrower's overall performance
            is rated satisfactory. Three major lessons emerge from
            project experience: 1) The implementation of Components 1
            and 2 underline the importance of continued broad
            consultation, good communication, and capacity building. The
            PRSP/CAS consultation of the Guinean population as to their
            priorities and the maintenance of a flow of information
            about budget allocations and priorities created strong
            expectations and pressures with regard to the
            decentralization of budgets, spending authority,
            procurement, and ultimately the improvement of public
            service delivery. The Borrower suggests that the
            beneficiaries may not have realized the full weight and
            scope of their new responsibilities under the decentralized
            budget and suggests that continuing efforts in training, in
            public information, and in providing local authorities with
            the means to carry out their responsibilities must be
            addressed in future operations. 2) Reagarding Component 3,
            the main lesson is that it is always difficult to advance
            structural reforms through adjustment lending, given the
            short time frame, the lack of investment leverage in the
            sector(s) concerned, and the absence of technical assistance
            to guide the process and provide analytical assistance. In
            this case, parallel implementation of a technical assistance
            and institutional development support project on the
            provision of funds in the budget could have maintained the
            dialogue, strengthened the Privatization Unit and the DNP,
            and carried on key studies such as company valuation and
            social impact. Other factors, which explain why the project
            could not move the disengagement process forward are that
            workers (often unionized) must be reassured that the state
            intends to look out for their welfare through consultation
            on measures related to re-employment, re-training, and
            self-employment. This requires substantial groundwork. While
            a communications firm was hired to develop a strategic plan
            in this area, this was too late to yield any results in the
            project's timeframe. 3) SAC IV demonstrates the
            importance of reforming budget procedures, notably through
            decentralization and the development of reliable mechanisms
            for monitoring and controlling public expenditure. Strong
            popular support for the reform program and the existence of
            tested mechanisms for consultation and communication could
            contribute to the success of a future PRSC.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Fourth Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project will support the three pillars of Guinea's
            poverty reduction strategy, and, cover the following
            reforms, designed to help improve public services,
            strengthen governance, and as a result, improve the
            environment for investment, and growth. The reforms aim to
            achieve: 1) more accountable, and efficient use of public
            resources, through improved public expenditure analysis, and
            management; 2) more effective government, through
            decentralization of decision-making, and service delivery;
            and, 3) improved public sector management, and more
            efficient resource use through divestiture. The successful
            implementation of the project will reinforce the
            Government's capacity to improve public service
            delivery, complement, and enhance the impact of other Bank
            interventions, and, contribute to restore credibility to
            public finances. However, risks affecting the reform program
            are the fragile security situation, significant shortfalls
            in revenue mobilization, which would threaten macroeconomic
            reforms, and, inadequate human, and institutional
            capacities, among others. Nonetheless, these risks are
            offset by the reestablishment of a credible macroeconomic
            environment, supported by strong political leadership, an
            Institutional Development Fund grant for governance, and
            integrity reforms to strengthen capacity, and, reforms in
            public sector management.

Guinea - Fourth Structural
